image.altText: A young blonde girl smiles at the camera

image.altText: John Woodman sits in a chair in front of a microphone against a wooden wall as he testifies at the IBAC hearing in Melbourne.

image.altText: Greg Jenkins 1

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank is hiking interest rates — and hitting borrowers — to fight high inflation, but data suggests the fight is being undermined by big-spending baby boomers.

image.altText: Image of couple in front of cancelled and sign and Metricon label

items.synopsis: Metricon, the biggest home builder in the country, has told some customers to pay painfully higher prices or risk losing their new homes and deposits in a contract nightmare affecting home owners.

image.altText: A Dutch player dribbles the ball as she is challenged by a USA opponent at the Women's World Cup.

items.synopsis: The USA and Netherlands finish deadlocked at 1-1 across the Tasman, as Australia prepares to cheer on the Matildas in their next group match against Nigeria this evening. Follow live.

title.children: USA, Netherlands play out tense World Cup draw, Matildas prepare for tonight's match

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Dramatic group-stage match, and it ends in a draw. After all that, the US will be more disappointed not to get the win, as they were so dominant after getting that equaliser. They looked unstoppable once they had their full array of attacking talent going full throttle, so well done to the Dutch for holding out. Still, I think it has shown some chinks in the US armour, as they looked pretty rattled for much of that first half and some of the second. Rose Lavelle, who I maintain is the best player to watch in the world, added the dynamism the US needed in the second half. I expect she'll start for them in the next game.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: FULL-TIME: USA 1 - 1 Netherlands

children.content: (Getty)
Dramatic group-stage match, and it ends in a draw. After all that, the US will be more disappointed not to get the win, as they were so dominant after getting that equaliser.
They looked unstoppable once they had their full array of attacking talent going full throttle, so well done to the Dutch for holding out.
Still, I think it has shown some chinks in the US armour, as they looked pretty rattled for much of that first half and some of the second.
Rose Lavelle, who I maintain is the best player to watch in the world, added the dynamism the US needed in the second half. I expect she'll start for them in the next game.
(PressBox)

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: My prediction is Australia 2 - 0 Nigeria. Goals from Raso and Gorry. You heard it here first.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Predictions time: Who's scoring the goals tonight?

children.content: My prediction is Australia 2 - 0 Nigeria.
Goals from Raso and Gorry.
You heard it here first.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Just as Van de Donk seemed to rile her up, Lindsey Horan does brilliantly from the corner, angling her run to the near post and heading home with power. It's 1-1! Really great header when you see it on replay, diverted with venom into the top corner.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: 62' HORAN scores for USA! It's 1-1

children.content: Just as Van de Donk seemed to rile her up, Lindsey Horan does brilliantly from the corner, angling her run to the near post and heading home with power.
Really great header when you see it on replay, diverted with venom into the top corner.
(Getty)

title.children: Police probe 'common link' between recent Sydney shootings after man gunned down in city's south-west

image.altText: Dancers hold up gumleaves as they dance inside the red-carpeted Legislative Council of Parliament House.

title.children: They're the oldest families in Victoria. On Wednesday, they took over Parliament House

image.altText: A man in high-vis sits on a ride-on lawnmower at night. He is being stopped by police.

image.altText: Jerome Powell stands at a podium behind a wall of American flags.

items.synopsis: The ASX has set a 100-day high as the market continues to digest yesterday's better than expected inflation numbers, while in the US, stocks finished flat as the Federal Reserve hikes interest rates to a 22-year high. Follow the day's events and insights from our business reporters on the ABC News live markets blog.

title.children: Fed 'prepared to raise further' as rates hit 22-year high, ASX up in early trade

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Planners, builders and insurers are calling on state governments to overhaul planning rules to stop building homes on flood plains. The Insurance Council of Australia, Master Builders Australia, and the Planning Institute of Australia, supported by the Australian Local Government Association, want planning rules changed so no more homes are built in high-risk flood prone locations. They held an industry round table to day to press their case. Planning ministers will report this year on developing a national standard for considering disaster and climate risk, and end development on flood plains. Here's Andrew Hall, chief executive of the Insurance Council of Australia. "The flood events of 2022, with almost 300,000 disaster-related claims costing around $7 billion, has driven up premiums and has resulted in affordability constraints for those at highest risk." Matt Collins, chief executive of the Planning Institute of Australia, says new risk based policies are needed to avoid or minimise exposure to floods. "Planning is a critical tool for influencing the level of future disaster risk, and our changing climate means we need to act now to limit the impact of extreme weather on our communities." Councillor Linda Scott, president of the Australian Local Government Association: "Australia’s 537 councils play a vital role in building resilient communities, assisting in every corner of the nation to ensure our communities can better prepare for, respond to and recover from increasing natural disasters." "It’s crucial we rebuild damaged local infrastructure to a more resilient standard."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Call to stop building homes in flood prone areas

children.content: Planners, builders and insurers are calling on state governments to overhaul planning rules to stop building homes on flood plains.

The Insurance Council of Australia, Master Builders Australia, and the Planning Institute of Australia, supported by the Australian Local Government Association, want planning rules changed so no more homes are built in high-risk flood prone locations.
They held an industry round table to day to press their case.
Planning ministers will report this year on developing a national standard for considering disaster and climate risk, and end development on flood plains.
Here's Andrew Hall, chief executive of the Insurance Council of Australia.
"The flood events of 2022, with almost 300,000 disaster-related claims costing around $7 billion, has driven up premiums and has resulted in affordability constraints for those at highest risk."
Matt Collins, chief executive of the Planning Institute of Australia,
says new risk based policies are needed to avoid or minimise exposure to floods.
"Planning is a critical tool for influencing the level of future disaster risk, and our changing climate means we need to act now to limit the impact of extreme weather on our communities."
Councillor Linda Scott, president of the Australian Local Government Association:

"Australia’s 537 councils play a vital role in building resilient communities, assisting in every corner of the nation to ensure our communities can better prepare for, respond to and recover from increasing natural disasters."
"It’s crucial we rebuild damaged local infrastructure to a more resilient standard."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The board of troubled infant formula company Bubs Australia has survived an attempt by dissident investors for an management overhaul. All resolutions put forward by a group of minority shareholders, who hold a 5 per cent stake, at an extraordinary general meeting today were defeated. The investors wanted to remove all four non-executive directors from the board in a campaign called "Save Our Bubs," saying the four, including chair Katrina Rathie, had presided over "the destruction of our great company." They also wanted former A2 Milk Asia boss Peter Nathan to become the new chief executive. In May, Bubs Australia sacked chief executive and co-founder Kristy Carr for allegedly failing to comply with reasonable board directions, however Ms Carr and sacked former executive chairman Dennis Lin are suing the firm for wrongful dismissal. Ms Carr has been leading the "Save Our Bubs" campaign. Chair Katrina Rathie says the company expects to appoint a new chief executive next month and has worked hard to improve board governance structures and transparency. "Excluding the requisitioners' votes, the board receiving resounding support and a clear mandate from more than 70 per cent of voted shares." "We acknowledge there is a lot of work to do, there are significant challenges, as well as great opportunities ahead and that shareholders expect to see a reversal of the company's performance over the past two years." The dissident investors put up former Elders deputy chairman James Jackson for the role of chairman, but he did not get enough votes. However, this battle is not over. Bubs Australia shares have slumped 13 per cent today. Watch this space.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Bubs board survives spill attempt

children.content: The board of troubled infant formula company Bubs Australia has survived an attempt by dissident investors for an management overhaul.
All resolutions put forward by a group of minority shareholders, who hold a 5 per cent stake, at an extraordinary general meeting today were defeated.
The investors wanted to remove all four non-executive directors from the board in a campaign called "Save Our Bubs," saying the four, including chair Katrina Rathie, had presided over
"the destruction of our great company."
They also wanted former A2 Milk Asia boss Peter Nathan to become the new chief executive.

In May, Bubs Australia sacked chief executive and co-founder Kristy Carr for allegedly failing to comply with reasonable board directions, however Ms Carr and sacked former executive chairman Dennis Lin are suing the firm for wrongful dismissal.
Ms Carr has been leading the "Save Our Bubs" campaign.
Chair Katrina Rathie says the company expects to appoint a new chief executive next month and has worked hard to improve board governance structures and transparency.
"Excluding the requisitioners' votes, the board receiving resounding support and a clear mandate from more than 70 per cent of voted shares."

"We acknowledge there is a lot of work to do, there are significant challenges, as well as great opportunities ahead and that shareholders expect to see a reversal of the company's performance over the past two years."
The dissident investors put up former Elders deputy chairman James Jackson for the role of chairman, but he did not get enough votes.
However, this battle is not over.
Bubs Australia shares have slumped 13 per cent today.
Watch this space.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Australian investment bank Macquarie Group's shares are down almost 5 per cent today after it highlighted a lower quarterly profit. In its update to the market, the group said low green energy investment-related income at its asset management arm had weighed on earnings. Macquarie did not give a profit figure in its quarterly update. Analysts at Citi said in a noted the group appeared to be anticipating further weakness through the 2024 fiscal year. "We think this reflects the collapse in YoY volatility in gas prices, consistent with declining capital consumption in CGM," analysts at Citi said. Macquarie Group flagged that trading activity in Macquarie Capital was expected to be up despite a challenging 2023.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Macquarie Group flags lower profit on weak green energy income

children.content: Australian investment bank
Macquarie Group's
shares are
down almost 5 per cent
today after it highlighted
a lower quarterly profit.
In its update to the market, the group said
low green energy investment-related income at its asset management arm had weighed on earnings
Macquarie did not give a profit figure in its quarterly update.
Analysts at Citi said in a noted the group appeared to be
anticipating further weakness through the 2024 fiscal year
"We think this reflects the collapse in YoY volatility in gas prices, consistent with declining capital consumption in CGM," analysts at Citi said.
Macquarie Group flagged that trading activity in Macquarie Capital was expected to be up despite a challenging 2023.
